This entrance to the Palais Royal station of the Paris metro on Place Colette is pleasantly surprising. It was located in the year 2000 and created by the artist Michel Othoniel. On an aluminum structure, the two identical domes decorated with Murano glass of different colors stand out. One represents the night and the other the day, each with its corresponding colors.

This is the entrance to Palais-Royal station, located at Place Colette in the 1st arrondissement of Paris. It's also near the Louvre Museum. This is the work of contemporary artist Jean-Michel Othoniel and was installed in 2000 to commemorate the 100th anniversary of the opening of the metro. Le Kiosque des Noctambules is entitled ``The Kiosk of the Nightlife''. It is made of two domes, one made of aluminum and one made of Murano glass, with the cool-colored dome representing the night and the warm-colored dome representing the day.

This metro station was very expensive for the RATP transport company in √éle-de-France for the transition to the year 2000 and therefore for us users. Despite everything, this work is worth the detour access is open and free this station is unique on the entire Parisian network

Le Kiosque des noctambules is a contemporary work of art by French visual artist Jean-Michel Othoniel located in the historic center of Paris The most spectacular metro entrance in Paris at the Palais Royal metro station in front of the garden and the French comedy Magnificent with its balls of all colors Always a pleasure to see her again

Palais Royal metro exit. It is a work commissioned by the Ministry of Culture. This work adorns the metro exit. We like it or we don't like it. We don't like it. But it remains to be seen. Beautiful reflections with the sun.

They change colors when night comes, the 800 giant Murano glass beads (attention, work of art, consult Wiki...).  That's it for the entrance to the metro, and I advise you to get off to admire another marvel: that of a Mexican shaman. Two million colored beads depict mythological themes. Not to be missed if you are touring the most beautiful metro stations

Very beautiful artistic work to mark the entrance to the royal palace metro. It does not stand out in this historic district despite the modernity of the work. Remarkable work by Murano glassmakers highlighted by Jean Michel Othoniel

kiosque des Noctambules, an artistic creation built on the Place Colette metro entrance. The style is very different from Guimard's classic¬†Art Nouveau¬†entrances. The staircase to access the metro is covered by two domes decorated with large colored Murano glass pearls. The first is decorated with warm colors to represent the day, the second with dark colors to represent the night. This decoration, created in 200 by the artist Jean Michel Othoniel on the occasion of the centenary of the Paris metro, makes the elegant atmosphere of the Place Colette magical and colourful.
Really pretty, this all-glass kiosk. There is a small bench to sit on. This work of art is by the artist, Jean-Michel Othoniel. Gorgeous ! A must see.
Magnificent metro stop, line 1 royal palace Louvre museum. Beautiful Murano glass balls, fantastic and magical structure. A feat of space design.

The NOCTAMBULES KIOSK,¬†Jean-Michel Othoniel¬†( 2000 ),¬†Place Colette Work of contemporary art installed on the exit/metro entrance of the Palais Royal ‚Äì Mus√©e du Louvre station, made up of a set of aluminum and Murano glass spheres, overlooking the¬†Place Colette, in front of the Palais building -Royal and the Com√©die-Fran√ßaise, Paris (1st). Commissioned from the French visual artist Jean-Michel Othoniel for the centenary of the construction of the Paris M√©tro in 2000, installed the same year and inaugurated on October 30. The work takes the form of an installation having the function of a¬†metro entrance. Outside, an aluminum metal mesh formed of rings linked to each other surrounds the staircase on three sides (apart from the one on which you can take it); it is set with a few rings of colored glass. Six columns made of aluminum spheres (three on each side of the mouth) support two domes. These domes are made up of a set of giant Murano glass beads (made by the Salviati glassworks) which appear to be strung together one after the other to form two dome-shaped structures. The dome which overlooks the entrance to the staircase is made of pearls in warm tones (yellow, white and red) and represents the day; the other has cold tones (blue, white, yellow and purple) and appears at night. Each of the domes is topped with a small sculpture of a glass figure. The back of the work includes a public bench, also made of aluminum. The interior part of the work, located shortly after the end of the staircase, contains two display cases embedded in the subway wall. They contain colored beads; one of the windows has warm tones, the other cold tones, like the two domes outside. In addition, the subway tiles at this entrance are painted a golden color; it finds its classic white color a little further on.

Very interesting station for its architecture. Imagined by Jean-Michel Othoniel according to the wish of the RATP, to celebrate the centenary of the Paris metro in 2000, the work is very poetic. I really liked these curves and spirals and, although the work took time to integrate into the urban space, it is very majestic. A real gem of art, located in the center of Paris.

The Kiosque des Noctambules is an entrance to the Palais Royal metro station created by Jean-Michel Othoniel. Quite spectacular at night. There are very few specific metro entrances in Paris, and this is one of the very few to have this special and recent entrance at the same time.

Infinite colorful madness! Jean-Michel Othoniel let loose while creating this sculpture. Located at Place Colette, it celebrates the centenary üíØ of the construction of the Paris metro. In reality, it is a metro entrance from the Palais Royal station, made up of a set of aluminum spheres and very colorful Murano glass. It is overlooked by two slender glass totems which embody the üåú and the üåû. The work draws an eight, symbol of infinity, harmony and eternity.
